item.title: MOOC List
item.description:
There’s a lot of MOOC classes I’d like to go through. I’ll update this post as I progress through each one. This make take several years.

Currently going through:

Udacity’s Git
Udacity’s Developing Android

Queued up:

  • Udacity - OOP JS
  • Udacity - Javascript Testing
  • Udacity - Intro to jQuery.
  • Udacity - Intro to Ajax.
  • Udacity - Web Development.
  • Udacity - Javascript Design Patterns.
  • Udacity - Full Stack Foundations.
  • Udacity - OAuth & Authorization.
  • Udacity Nano Degree - Front End.
  • Udacity - Intro to Algo.
  • Coursera - Algo 1.
  • Udacity Nano Degree - Full Stack.
  • Coursera - Algo 2.

Completed:
Udacity - Intro to Android - June 2015

Edit 6/26/12: as much as I’d love to learn all these topics, it would behoove me to focus. Decided to move web related courses down to focus on Android dev.

item.title: Reading List
item.description:
This my reading list for programming. I’ll update it with notes as I read them through my career.

Currently going through:

Code Complete: A Practical Handbook of Software Construction

To read:

  • Mythical Man Month
  • Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software
  • Introduction to Algorithms
  • Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs
  • Pragmatic Programmer
  • Clean Code: A Handbook of Agile Software Craftsmanship
  • Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software
  • Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools
  • The Little Schemer
  • Programming Pearls
  • The New Turing Omnibus

Sources:
Jeff Atwood’s recommended reading for developers.
Peteris Krumins’ top 100 books part 1.
Peteris Krumins’ top 100 books part 2.
Peteris Krumins’ top 100 books part 3.

item.title: CoderByte
item.description:
I’ll update my progress with CoderByte in this post. Answers are up on this github repo.

6/14/15 - finished with 28/30 Easy ones. While analyzing other user’s methods, I noticed how ‘elementary’ my methods are (using arrays to temporary hold my answers instead of just returning the answer, lack of functional javascript, etc.). I’m looking forward to seeing my progress when I attempt the same questions in several months.
